instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 with no boot.

It powers on, I have 20V on ampmeter, and it goes to 4A with battery, and 0.609A with the board on the desk alone.

Already tried revive and restore DFU with no sucess.

It has fan spin, CPU gets hot, but have no USB activity.

On big coils I get:

LA350 = 0.902V
LA300 = 1.351V
LA650 = 0.902V
LA640 = 0.903V
LA340 = 0.903V
L7231 = 0V
L7330 = 0V
L7221 = 0V
L7211 = 0V
L7420 = 0V
L7410 = 0V

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
Any history available?
DFU ends with error?

Compare diode mode on the coils with good board.; especially the ones without voltage.

Did you check L7700/1 and L8102 voltage?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
Hi, No history. It stoped working overnight client says.
DFU finishes without any message at all. Just goes to the blocket lock image after finishing the restore step 4.
Unfortunently I have no other board  to test...

L7700 = 2.489V
L7701 = 1.201V
L8102 = 0.954V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
Inspect all components around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
You may have PCH, or CPU problems.
<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN_R</SIGNAL> comes high?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
Hi,

Right now it started to reboot by it self. It reaches 1.5A and power cycles.

However, now,  I get 0.939V on L7231, L7221, L7330 and L7211. The only ones that remains with 0V are L7410 and L7420

Components around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> seam ok. <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN_R</SIGNAL> comes to 1.0V.

I notice that <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> and UA600 gets hot on thermal cam, and not know if it is relevant. Is it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
L7410/20 correspond to iGPU; don't expect to get voltage there yet.
CPU core should drop to 0.6V aprox, when board boots.
Starts with 0.939V and never drops a bit?

How much time to reboots?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
It takes around 40 seconds to reboot.

Actualy, on CPUCORE SW1/2 ÃŽ get 1.125V and on <SIGNAL>CPUCORE_SW3</SIGNAL> I have 1.248V.

On <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL>/3 I have 0.939V and  stays like that until reboot.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
Why do you check in front of buck converter coil (SW side)?
There is no real DC voltage; check ALWAYS at the output pin of the coil, for DC voltage.
And, in case like this with 2-3 coils tied together, why do you need to check all of them?

Reflash <CHIP>U4770</CHIP> and try again DFU restore.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
HI, tks, and sorry for the ignorance. Still learning...

I've never flashed <CHIP>U4770</CHIP>. I suppose that I can Use the BY-T200 to do it, but I don't have the file to flash. Do you have it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
You can use any BIOS programmer, with correct adapter for 1.8V and small package.
Try this one...
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1EF4nvQCUzYOKFg_37zCrfq1KvgrvKO8B/view?usp=share_link[/URL]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
Hi, I managed to program <CHIP>U4770</CHIP> with the new file. However, when restoring in DFU I get an error, and full fan spin.
Any idea?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message: Try again flashing back original SoC ROM.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
Hi,
Same error in DFU restore, after restoring original Soc ROM, but I just realize that now, I only get 5.16V from ampmeter.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message:
Hi,
Should I give up on it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no boot
threads.message: Nor even Apple has a clear response for T2 error messages.
